German

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • giessen (Switzerland, Liechtenstein)

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German gie»•en, from Old High German gio»•an, from Proto-West Germanic *geutan (‚Äúto pour‚Äù).

Akin to Dutch gieten, Old Saxon giotan, Old English ƒ°ƒìotan, Old Norse gj√≥ta (whence Danish gyde, Swedish gjuta), Gothic êå≤êåπêåøêçÑêå∞êåΩ (giutan). Compare English gush.

Further Indo-European cognates include Latin fund≈ç (‚Äúto pour, to smelt‚Äù), Ancient Greek œáŒ≠œâ (kh√©≈ç, ‚Äúto pour‚Äù) and Sanskrit ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø (juh√≥ti, ‚Äúhe sacrifices‚Äù). More at geysa, yote and found.

The sense of pouring metals and glasses is attested since Old High German times through the participle gigo»•»•an (‚Äúpoured, smelted, made by casting‚Äù).[1]

Verb

[edit]

gie√üen (class 2 strong, third-person singular present gie√üt, past tense goss, past participle gegossen, past subjunctive g√∂sse, auxiliary haben)

  1. (transitive) to pour; usually only of liquids, especially of large quantities
    Synonym: sch√ºtten (preferred with small quantities, also used of solids)
    Das √ñl wird in die Tanks gegossen. ‚Äï The oil is poured into the tanks.
    Bleigie√üen ‚Äï lead-pouring
  2. (transitive) to pour; to cast; to found (shape molten metal or glass by pouring)
    Die Statue wurde vom K√ºnstler selbst gegossen. ‚Äï The statue was cast by the artist himself.
    Stahlgie√üen ‚Äï steel pouring
  3. (transitive, horticulture) to water by pouring (e.g. with a can)
    Coordinate term: (by spraying) sprengen
    die Blumen gie√üen ‚Äï to water the flowers
    Gie√ükanne ‚Äï watering can
  4. (impersonal, intransitive, of rain) to pour down; to rain strongly
    Synonym: sch√ºtten
    Es gie√üt. ‚Äï It‚Äôs pouring.
    Es gie√üt wie aus K√ºbeln/Eimern. ‚Äï It‚Äôs raining cats and dogs. (literally, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pouring as though out of buckets.‚Äù)
